outputs.executiveSummary: This value case estimates the gross margin (GM) upside from two near-term levers: (A) personalised loyalty activation within Club New Look and (C) price optimisation/markdown governance. We first estimate loyalty-linked sales using New Look’s FY25 revenue of £687.7m [2][3], then apply conservative, evidence-bounded uplifts to the most relevant revenue pools and convert to GM using the blended margin of 48.1% [2][3]. Club New Look launched nationally on 27 October 2025 with a 25% welcome offer and ongoing ‘Club Prices’, after a soft launch that reached 500,000 sign-ups and a stated target of 800,000 members [1][7]. With discounting pressure explicitly cited in FY25 [2][3], tightening price architecture and markdown rules is a timely GM lever. Because the base case using midpoint uplifts clears the £2m GM threshold, we keep median (not stretch) assumptions across all levers to avoid best-case dependency and maintain CFO-grade conservatism.

slide2_loyaltySentimentSnapshot.summary: Because Club New Look only launched nationally on 27 October 2025 [1], public feedback explicitly tagged to the programme is still limited. The best available last-12-month sentiment signal comes from high-volume customer feedback on New Look’s digital experience (delivery, returns, customer service), which is highly relevant to loyalty enrolment, engagement and repeat purchasing. Sentiment is mixed: customers still highlight finding value and ‘bargains’, but negative themes dominate around refund delays, difficulty contacting a human, and frustration with automated chat/support. This feedback is primarily from general customers rather than confirmed loyalty members, but it indicates the friction points that can suppress loyalty adoption and reduce the realised value of Club New Look if not addressed alongside personalisation and offer strategy.

table.Area of Impact: A. Personalised Loyalty (incl. offer waste reduction)
table.Opportunity Type: Incremental GM from better targeting and reduced discount waste
table.Assumptions / Methodology:
1. UPLIFT POINT APPLIED
We have applied a 1.0% uplift, which represents the median of the credible range for this lever.

2. RANGE & SOURCE
This sits within the credible category range of 0.5% to 2.0%, based on New Look’s evidenced investments in data unification and personalisation-enabling platforms (CDP and marketing automation) [11][12].

3. WHY THIS POINT WAS SELECTED
We selected this point because the total value case was above the 2 million pound threshold, which means the model uses the median rule.

4. SIMPLE MATHS EXPLANATION
In practice, this means applying the 1.0% uplift to loyalty-member revenue (estimated at £137.5m), and converting this into gross margin using the blended GM% of 48.1%.

5. RESULT
This results in an estimated gross margin uplift of £0.7m for this lever.

6. REASSURANCE
All assumptions sit comfortably within evidence-based bounds and avoid reliance on extreme best-case scenarios.

table.Opportunity Type: GM uplift from improved price architecture and markdown management
table.Assumptions / Methodology:
1. UPLIFT POINT APPLIED
We have applied a 0.8% uplift, which represents the median of the credible range for this lever.

2. RANGE & SOURCE
This sits within the credible category range of 0.3% to 1.5%, based on FY25 evidence that higher discounting was required to clear stock, signalling a material optimisation opportunity in markdown and pricing governance [2][3].

3. WHY THIS POINT WAS SELECTED
We selected this point because the total value case was above the 2 million pound threshold, which means the model uses the median rule.

4. SIMPLE MATHS EXPLANATION
In practice, this means applying the 0.8% uplift to total revenue (£687.7m), and converting this into gross margin using the blended GM% of 48.1%.

5. RESULT
This results in an estimated gross margin uplift of £2.6m for this lever.

6. REASSURANCE
All assumptions sit comfortably within evidence-based bounds and avoid reliance on extreme best-case scenarios.

1. UPLIFT POINT APPLIED
We have applied a combined uplift consistent with the median of the credible ranges for each lever, summed on a gross-margin basis.

2. RANGE & SOURCE
This sits within the combined credible bounds implied by the lever ranges (Personalised Loyalty 0.5% to 2.0% on loyalty revenue; Price Optimisation 0.3% to 1.5% on total revenue), grounded in New Look’s data/personalisation investments and FY25 discounting pressure [2][3][11][12].

3. WHY THIS POINT WAS SELECTED
We selected this point because the total value case was above the 2 million pound threshold, which means the model uses the median rule.

4. SIMPLE MATHS EXPLANATION
In practice, this means adding the GM uplift from Personalised Loyalty (£0.7m) to the GM uplift from Price Optimisation (£2.6m), with both levers converted using the blended GM% of 48.1%.

5. RESULT
This results in an estimated total gross margin uplift of £3.3m.

6. REASSURANCE
All assumptions sit comfortably within evidence-based bounds and avoid reliance on extreme best-case scenarios.
